tit.cmt: 以下説明が続くので、英語説明を削除しました。

sen.j: 如意ケ嶽の戦い（にょいがたけのたたかい）は、永正6年（1509年）6月17日の夜半に京都市左京区の如意ケ嶽周辺で行われた戦い。
sen.e: The Battle of Nyoigatake was fought near Mt. Nyoigatake in Sakyo ward of Kyoto City at midnight of July 14, 1509.

sen.e: Whether it developed into a great battle or not, whether they attempted to invade Koto again or not, and whether they attempted to force their way back to Awa Province or not remained unknown.

sen.j: 永正の錯乱で細川澄元や三好之長は一旦近江国の甲賀に引いたが、すぐさま京に侵攻し細川澄之派をことごとく討ち取った。
sen.e: In Eisho Disturbance, Sumimoto HOSOKAWA and Yukinaga MIYOSHI withdrew to Koga in Omi Province once, but they immediately invaded Kyoto and defeated the entire army of Sumiyuki HOSOKAWA.

sen.e: The former Seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the eastern barbarians") Yoshitane ASHIKAGA, who had been expelled in Coup of Meio, attempted to take advantage of the disorder and go up to Kyoto, trusting in Yoshioki OUCHI.

sen.e: Saw it coming, Sumimoto HOSOKAWA asked Shigeyuki HOSOKAWA, his grandfather, and Takakuni HOSOKAWA to plan to be reconciled with those including Yoshioki OUCHI together.

sen.j: 同年4月9日、摂津国の主だった国衆達は細川高国方につき、また大内義興軍が接近しつつある情勢を不利と読んだ細川澄元や三好之長は、自らの屋敷に火を放ち再び近江国に落ち延びた。
sen.e: On May 18, 1508, Sumimoto HOSOKAWA and Yukinaga MIYOSHI realized the disadvantage of having a band of kunishu (local samurais) who ruled Settsu Province take the side of Takakuni HOSOKAWA and also of the army of Yoshioki OUCHI be close at hand, set fire to their residence and fled to Omi Province again.

sen.j: 翌4月10日細川高国は入京、同年6月9日足利義稙は堺から入洛し、同年7月1日に再び将軍職につき、細川高国には管領職を大内義興には管領代職にそれぞれ任じられた。
sen.e: On the next day, May 19, 1508, Takakuni HOSOKAWA entered the capital of Kyoto; on July 16, 1508, Yoshitane ASHIKAGA came into Kyoto from Sakai; and on August 7, 1508, Yoshitane ASHIKAGA assumed the office of shogun again, appointed Takakuni HOSOKAWA kanrei (shogunal deputy) and appointed Yoshioki OUCHI kanrei dai (representative of a shogunal deputy), respectively.

sen.j: その後、摂津国の国衆で細川澄元派であった池田貞政は討死、阿波国に逃れたようとした芥川豊後守も台風で遭難、近江国からだと徴兵もままならず、細川澄元は八方ふさがりの状態に陥っていた。
sen.e: After that, Sumimoto HOSOKAWA was hemmed in on all sides -- Sadamasa IKEDA who was a kunishu of Settsu Province and took the side of Sumimoto HOSOKAWA died in battle, Akutagawa Bungo no kami (governor of Bungo Province) wrecked in typhoon on his way to Awa Province retreat, and there had been little progress in draft enrollment from Omi Province.

sen.j: この状況を打開するため細川澄元、三好之長軍は、翌永正6年（1509年）6月に琵琶湖を渡り、小関越から同6月17日に如意ケ嶽に3千名で陣をひいた。
sen.e: To break the deadlock, the armies under the command of Sumimoto HOSOKAWA and Yukinaga MIYOSHI proceeded over Lake Biwa in June in the next year 1509, and on July 14, 1509, from Kozekigoe, the army of three thousand men encamped on Mt. Nyoigatake.

sen.j: これに対して細川高国、大内義興連合軍は2万-3万兵で如意ケ嶽を取り込むように陣をひいた。
sen.e: To cope with them, the allied forces of Takakuni HOSOKAWA and Yoshioki OUCHI of twenty to thirty thousands men encamped around Mt. Nyoigatake.

sen.j: その後戦闘状態に突入したが、夜半から大雨がふり出し細川澄元、三好之長らは雨音にまぎれて阿波国へ落ち延びていった。
sen.e: Then, the two sides engaged in battle, but, as it began to rain heavily around midnight, Sumimoto HOSOKAWA, Yoshioki OUCHI and others ran away through the roaring sound of the heavy downpour to Awa Province.

sen.j: また永正5年（1508年）4月10日細川高国が入京時期に、逆に足利義澄は京から落ち延びて九里氏を頼って近江岡山城に落ち延びたが、同年10月2日に細川高国と大内義興は追討軍を差し向け岡山城の戦いに続く。
sen.e: On May 19, 1508, Takakuni HOSOKAWA entered the capital of Kyoto; in contrast, Yoshizumi ASHIKAGA fled from Kyoto to Okayama Castle in Omi Province trusting in the Kuri clan, and on November 4, 1508, Takakuni HOSOKAWA and Yoshioki OUCHI dispatched a punitive force after Yoshizumi, which led to the Battle of Okayama Castle.
